Visualize diversity or abundance as a boxplot, dotplot, etc.

Source: R/plot.r
plot.Rd

Visualize diversity or abundance as a boxplot, dotplot, etc.

# S3 method for BIOM
plot(
  x,
  formula,
  layers = "box",
  color.by = NULL,
  facet.by = NULL,
  stats = TRUE,
  vline = "ci95",
  xlab.angle = "auto",
  ...
)

Arguments

x

A BIOM object, as returned from read.biom.
formula

Definition of the y-axis metric and metadata column to plot along the x-axis. For example, Shannon ~ `Body Site`. Y-axis options are:

Alpha Diversity Metrics (one or more)

OTUs, Shannon, Chao1, Simpson, and/or InvSimpson. Use Diversity to get all five metrics.

Beta Diversity Metrics (one only)

manhattan, euclidean, bray-curtis, jaccard, or unifrac. Distance will use unifrac if a phylogenetic tree is present, or bray-curtis otherwise. Use in combination with the weighted parameter. Metadata column names can be prefixed with == or != to limit distance calculations to within or between, respectively, those categories. See examples below.

Taxa Abundances (one only)

Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species, Strain, or OTU. Supported ranks will vary by biom. Run taxa.ranks(biom) to see the available options. Specifying Abundance will default to the most precise rank possible.
layers

What kind of plot to create. Options are box, violin, dot, strip, crossbar, errorbar, linerange, and/or pointrange. Single letter abbreviations are also accepted. For instance, c("box", "dot") is equivalent to c("b", "d") and "bd".
color.by

Metadata column to color by. If that column is a factor, the ordering of levels will be maintained in the plot.
facet.by

A character vector of one or two metadata columns to facet by. Ordering of factor levels will be maintained in the plot.
stats

How to display significance brackets and p-values on the plot. Options are:

TRUE

Auto-select pairwise or group. (Default)

FALSE

Do not display significance values on the plot.

"p" or "pairwise"

Compare all against all.

"g" or "group"

Compute a single p-value per group.

data.frame

Data to use for statistical annotations. I.e. from stats.table.
vline

How to calculate min/max of the crossbar, errorbar, linerange, and pointrange layers. Options are ci (confidence interval), sd (standard deviation), se (standard error), and mad (median absolute deviation). You may optionally append a number to ci to specify the confidence level, for instance vline = "ci95" (the default), will calculate the 95 confidence interval, whereas vline = "ci99" will give the 99 interval.
xlab.angle

How to rotate the tick labels on the x-axis. 'auto' (the default), automatically selects a rotation value. 0, 30, and 90 sets the angle to horizontal, angled, and vertical, respectively.
...

Parameters passed on to ggplot2 functions. Prefixing a parameter name with b., v., d., or s. forces that parameter to be passed to, and only to, geom_boxplot, geom_violin, geom_dotplot, or geom_jitter, respectively. Otherwise, parameters are passed along by matching against formal arguments.

Value

A ggplot2 plot. The computed data points and statistics will be attached as attr(p, 'data') and attr(p, 'stats'), respectively.

See also

stats.table

Examples

    library(rbiom)
    
    infile <- system.file("extdata", "hmp50.bz2", package = "rbiom")
    biom <- read.biom(infile)
    
    plot(biom, Shannon ~ `Body Site`)

    plot(biom, Shannon ~ Sex, layers="vb", color.by="Body Site")

    
    plot(biom, Diversity ~ `Body Site`, layers="p", color.by="Sex", xlab.angle=30)

#> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (geom_pointrange).
    
    #plot(biom, UniFrac ~ `==Body Site`)
    
    plot(biom, bray ~ nmds)
